announced two weeks ago fiscal
cutbacks that include the closing
of Newman House and the
reassigning of its two priests.
The cutbacks, effective
February 3, were surprising in
part because they were announced
to the public without any prior
warning to the Hopkins Catholic
community.

D'Amario's reaction was typical.

deficits in its upcoming budget.

Hopkins students for years.

Catholic Community, explained
that Newman House begain in
1949 when someone donated it to
the Archdiocese to be used as a
campus ministry. Gale said
Newman House was popular in
the 1950s and 1960s but lost
momentum in the 1970s. Recently, however, the Newman House

Several new fraternities aim to fill voids
Presidents hope to bridge gap between Greeks and non-Greeks
by Vensive Lamb
and Alex Pham
Dissatisfied with the old Greek
network, four new fraternities
have formed, breaking from what
they view as standard molds that
characterize many established
Hopkins fraternities.
Formed in the last two years,
these four fraternities—Beta
Theta Pi, Kappa Sigma, Sigma
Alpha Mu and Sigma Phi
Epsilon—perceived needs at
Hopkins not met by established
fraternities.
"The fraternities at Hopkins
have set themselves into stone in
the roles that they play," said
Richard Bell. president of Beta
Theta Pi. "They've been too
standardized for years."
Bill Woodcock, president of
Kappa Sigma, concurred, saying
his fraternity was formed to
"bridge the gap that used to exist between the Greek system and
the non-Greek student body."
Sigma Alpha Mu President
Jonathan Missner said his fraternity "felt we had a lot to offer this
campus. We also felt that we
could strengthen the Greek
system by offering a wider selection to those interested in joining
a fraternity."
The expressed enthusiasm of
the new Greeks is complemented
by positive support from the preexisting fraternities.
Tim Rosenzweig, president of
Alpha Tau Omega, observed,
"The new fraternities have attracted guys who may not have
gone Greek in the past."
The diversity the new fraternities offer is commanding the attention of older chapter members.
Ted Kim, Rush Co-Chairman of
Delta Phi (St. Elmo's), saw this
diversity as a strength because it
allowed fraternities to reach an
even wider group of rushees."
"We want to be a diverse
fraternity with a strong sense of
tradition," said Bell. "We want
to pursue a number of aspects, including being active members of
the Hopkins community."
Intrafraternity Council President Joe Sokolowski said of

fraternities, "They've more or
less changed the face of all the
fraternities in dispelling the
Animal House myth of why a
fraternity exists. They don't exist solely to provide social life.
They also provide a service for
their brothers and the whole
community."
Continuing the tradition of
community service offered by the
Hopkins Greek system, new
chapters and colonies participate
actively in various philanthropic
endeavors.
Sigma Alpha Mu, for example,
raised enough money last
semester to feed over 500
homeless persons Thar'-sgiving
dinner. Members of Kap,a Sigma
sponsored a Students Against
Multiple Sclerosis volleyball
game and visited area nursing
homes. Other fraternities are
planning community serviceoriented projects for this
semester.
The increased visibility
generated in part by the new
fraternities has fueled a desire for
similar developments in the
Hopkins sorority system.
Karen Rappaport, president of
the Panhellenic Council, expressed the possibility of the sorority
system's expansion through the

addition of another sorority. Rappaport explained that an additional sorority could better serve
the growing demand of Hopkins
women for Greek life, as
evidenced in the increasing
number of women wanting to join
the ranks of Alpha Phi and Phi
Mu.
Currently Alpha Phi has
eighty-six members and Phi Mu
counts over 100 members, including pledges.
Rappaport added that further
expansion of these numbers could
jeopardize the quality of the two
sororities.
On the other hand, some fraternity members view additions to
the fraternity system skeptically.
"There is going to be a point
where we have to not let any
more chapters into the system,"
said Kris Mauren, president of
Delta Phi,"but the time is probably not now since next year's
freshman class is likely to grow
in accordance with the Five-Year
Plan."
He further maintained that he
would not be against the formation of another fraternity, though
he believes the choices now
available are adequate considering the influx of the four young
fraternities.

Hoppy HoUr hit
by administrative
scheduling conflicts
by Anne Langley
Beware all loyal Hoppy Hour
attenders! Hoppy hour the most
popular way on campus to make
the transition into the weekend,
will no longer be held as often
this semester. Hopkins will see
only five Hoppy Hours this
semester, rather than one every
Friday.
Other events have pre-empted
Hoppy Hour, so the event will
take place only on February 17,
March 3 and 10, and April 21 and
28.
What happened? The problem
is simple—a lack of space on
campus.
The Glass Pavilion is the only
room large enough to accommodate Hoppy Hour. Last year,
when scheduling conflicts were
encountered, Hoppy Hour was
held in the Great Hall, but this
space proved too small and
created problems, hence limiting
the event from that point on to the
Glass Pavilion.
Unfortunately, the Glass
Pavilion is required for any large
event, and many such events fall
on Friday afternoons this
semester. "It is a matter of coincidence," said Lis Borja, cochair of the Student Council
Social Committee, which is in
charge of planning Hoppy Hour.

"There are a lot of one-.time conflicts, and we have to
compromise."
Kathy Wachsman, scheduling
coordinator for the Student Activities Commission, agreed that
the conflicts were a coincidence
and expressed regret that few
large areas made scheduling extremely restricted and inflexible:
"These are big events and the
Glass Pay is the only possibility,"
she said.
Wachsman became aware of
the Hoppy Hour conflict in midDecember and contacted Susan
Boswell, dean of students, but no
alternatives could be found for
either Hoppy Hour or the other
events. As Wachsman said, "It is
a student union, but the entire
University is entitled to use it.
Some of these events are very important to the University. Where
do you draw the line?"
Events being held this semester
instead of Hoppy Hour include a
Security Office banquet, an
Amnesty International event, an
Engineering anniversary reception, and a HOBI Youth Foundation kick-off meeting, sponsored
by Dean of Homewood Schools
Services Chris Colombo's office.
Each of these is a one-time event
that was scheduled quite a while
ago and can be held only in the
Glass Pavilion.

Yet again, Orientation pay under review
by Aaron Goldenberg
Debate has begun once again
on a plan that would pay Orientation and student advising cochairs as much as $1,500 each.
Although details and financial
specifications for the plan have
yet to be determined, the plan's
backers maintain that it is
necessary to attract applicants to
the positions. Many potential
volunteers, it is believed, do not
apply because they need to maintain summer incomes. The Orientation positions are currently
unpaid.
According to Susan Boswell,
dean of students, and Andrea
Perry, director of residential life,
the plan originated about two
years ago when former Dean of
Students Chris Columbo
established a committee to look
into ways in which other "peer
institutions" handled their student
orientation programs.
The committee was formed,
according to Perry, in response to
a dwindling applicant pool for the
positions of Orientation chair and
co-chair.
The results of the committee,
Boswell said, indicated that most
schools paid students in "one way
or another." The Student Council, however, voted down the proposal at the time. Hopkins currently allows Orientation chairs
university housing over the
summer.

serious communication problems

because last summer's advising

because she worked as an assistant in the Residential Life office.

Avoiding 'Happenstance'
At universities that manage
their budgets centrally, the provost or budget director might
review every financial allocation
with a fine-tooth comb. Decentralized institutions delegate such
detail to their divisions. As a
result, administrators say, financial decisions are better informed.
"The bottom line is that the

shifts might be the same. Before,
they were happenstance. Now,
they're deliberate," says Lyn
Hutton, senior vice-president at
U.S.C.
To help its departments and
schools better understand their
financial status, U.S.C. installed
a $2-million computer system in
1982 capable of providing daily
readings on income and costs,
and how those figures compare
with targets set at the beginning
of each year.
The system allows the heads of
academic divisions—or "revenue
centers," as they're called at
U.S.C.—to make mid-course
corrections in _case a revenue

shortfall becomes apparent. By
November, for example, a school
will know whether it should take
the revenue-increasing step of admitting more students for springsemester courses.
A dean might also ask a faculty member to quicken the pace of
a sponsored research project, in
order to speed the flow of
research dollars to the university, says John Curry, U.S.C.'s
vice-president for budget and
planning.

Infighting is one reason Northwestern has opted against a

By bringing all revenue into

For a variety of reasons, Indiana University, which has been
planning for a decentralized

that fiscal considerations will

Whalen, director of budgeting at

$11-Million Shortfall at
Stanford
Even those universities that try
decentralization can't anticipate
every contingency. Stanford
University, which in the last two
years has begun moving toward
decentralized budgeting, recently projected an $11-million shortfall for 1989-90, and is now planning cuts to close the gap. The
university is trying to raise
$1.1 -billion, but has attracted
fewer unrestricted donations than
expected and faces unanticipated
costs and revenue shortfalls in
several academic areas.
Another concern about decen-

tralized budget plans is that they
can, like other schemes, break
down.
"When a university cuts its
faculty 10 per cent after raising
half a billion dollars, it's a very,
very bad situation," says Jerrold
S. Cooper, chairman of the Near
Eastern Studies department at
Johns Hopkins.
Until last year, Hopkins had no
serious problems with longstanding disparities between its
School of Arts and Sciences,
which is not well endowed, and
its School of Medicine, which has
not had problems attracting
funds.
But without a mechanism for
sharing surpluses among schools,
Hopkins officials faced a dilemma when they projected deficits
in arts and sciences and other programs that would outgrow the
capacity of a modest central
discretionary fund. Now,
however, the university will draw
$27-million over the next five
years from the medical school
and five other profitable divisions
to help bail out deficit-ridden
programs.
But the fix is only temporary,
increasing the pressure for cutbacks in arts and sciences and
other areas.
Many people angrily blame administrators for failing to anticipate problems earlier and for
fiscal mismanagement. Some say
the financial troubles threaten the
university's academic reputation.
But few have questioned the
budget system itself. "Decentralizaiton is a strength of
Hopkins," says Lloyd Armstrong, Jr., dean of arts and
sciences. "It shows the strength
of the structure that in times of
need, we are able to come
together and voluntarily reconfigure ourselves so we can get
over our difficulties."

Saving the Community
Members of the Hopkins Catholic
Community were shocked to learn last
week of the Baltimore Archdiocese's
abrupt decision to cut all funding for the
organization effective June 30 as part of
a larger series of fiscal cutbacks implemented to avoid a deficit next year.
With only nominal funding from the
University, the community will have
virtually no means of support.
While we at Hopkins have become all
too familiar lately with fiscal cutbacks,
sacrifices and reduced services, the Archdiocese's decision will hit particularly
hard. The Catholic Community is a
large and active student group at
Homewood. Under the guidance of
Fathers John Donohue and Bob
Michele, the community provides a
variety of services and programs including Sunday Mass on campus, as
well as on days of obligation and weekly
"Newman Nights" of dinner, discussion, and fellowship. The community
works closely with the Office of the
Chaplain, and has co-sponsored such
activities as Thanksgiving Dinner.
Particularly valuable, however, in
this divisive campus, is the sense of
enmmunity and belonging the organiza-

tion conveys to its members. The
Catholic Community provides weekly
opportunitites to interact socially and in- •
tellectually with a wide range of people in a relaxed, homelike setting. Such
opportunities, which are open to all, are
rare at Homewood.
The Archdiocese's decision to cut the
community's funding makes sense from
a purely fiscal standpoint: "studentparishes" simply do not generate
enough revenue to cover themselves.
Scarce resources must be allocated accordingly and in the neediest areas.
However, we do urge the Archdiocese
to reconsider its decision in terms of the
impact it will have at Homewood and
on its students. Approximately thirty
percent of the student population here
is Roman Catholic, about 150-200
students attend campus Sunday Mass,
and many more avail themselves of the
other programs and services.
It is therefore important to a large
number of students that a Catholic
presence be maintained at Hopkins. The
Archdiocese must surely consider the
spiritual needs of Catholic students at
a secular university very important.

As the debate continues—Is the
bookstore run by a bunch of
crooks, or do a bunch of crooks
run the bookstore?—one of the
oldest descriptions of the Hopkins
student has arisen by way of explanation. We are, goes conventional wisdom, altogether too
apathetic. Uninterested. Selfish.
What garbage.
Hopkins students are far from
apathetic, and we do not serve
ourselves by allowing this erroneous assumption to continue,
especially because it can be used
against us.
Two groups wind up citing this
alleged apathy with great
regularity. First (and more
forgivably), those trying to get
campuswide initiatives off the
ground, be it demand for improved housing or social programming, sometimes find themselves
frustrated when attendance is
poor or interest is low.
Understandably so, although the
success of recent ventures such as
Hoppy Hour and (ahem) Funk
Night would seem to attest
otherwise.
Second, and far less acceptable, the Administration often
ducks much needed reforms
(even when suggested by the
Human Climate Report) if they
aren't worried about student
response. Fair enough, one supposes, from their point of view.
Hopkins student activism,
rather, has been shaped by forces
which are unique to our school.
Because we are spread out all
over the Homewood area thanks

to our housing situation, the flip
side to life here is that we are integrated with the general community to a greater extent than
students at many other schools.
As a result, student involvement has not been of the campus
oriented variety, with all of the
ingrown ivory-tower perceptions
of the world beyond that can accompany more insular institutions. For a true picture of what
Hopkins is about, one has to look

ADMISSIONS OFFICE
STUDENT INTERN PROGRAM
The Office of Admissions is opening a search for senior
admissions interns for the fall of 1989. We are looking for
people-oriented students to assist in the recruitment process by conducting the traditional on-campus interview.
Ideal candidates will enjoy speaking with prospective
students and their parents. Students must be poised and
mature and possess tact, diplomacy and the ability to put
high school students and their parents at ease.
To be eligible, a student must be a senior next fall in
good standing and plan to graduate in May 1990. Interns
must be able to talk about Johns Hopkins in an informed
and positive way, have a desire to participate in the
recruitment process and be comfortable interacting with
others.
Interns will be responsible for conducting admissions
interviews with prospective students and meeting their
parents and responding to their questions and concerns.
In addition, interns will compose written summary reports
of each interview. This will involve three or four hour-long
interviews each week from mid-September through midDecember. These are paid positions.
The initial interviews of interns will take place on March
28, 29 and 30 with second interviews scheduled on April
4, 5 and 6. The training program for those interns selected
will be just after final examinations and at the begilning
of first semester next year. Interns must be available at
these times.
Any student interested should send a letter indicating
his or her interest and listing two references, to Jerome
D. Schnyt man, Director of Admissions. Both references
must be members of the Johns Hopkins community,
preferably one member of the faculty and one from the
administration. Students should apply by March 10.

story equals 12 feet). According to
UCLA physiologist Jared Diamond. "this phenomena has not

Whitney and Mehlhaff explain
the difference between cat and
human injuries using a few basic
principles of physics. Severity of
injuries is determined by the
stress a body experiences at impact. Impact stress is related to a
number of factors.
First, impact stress is directly
proportional to force. Force is
partially determined by the
distance fallen. As a body falls,
its velocity increases. The greater
the velocity at impact, the greater
the force. Force is also affected
by body mass—greater mass
equals greater force. The hardness of the surface also contributes to impact force. Softer
surfaces tend to 'give,' which
reduces the force applied to the
body. In this study, however,
almost all of the cats fell to concrete pavement.
Impact stress is inversely proportional to the area of the cat
which hits the ground. For instance, as a cat falls it twists
around until all four feet are facing downward. When the cat
lands, stress is evenly distributed
over four limbs. When human
adults fall, they tumble uncontrollably and usually land on
either their legs or their head.
When human babies fall, the
relatively large size of their heads
causes them to fall on their heads
while their arms extend outward
by reflex to break the fall. Consequently, stress is distributed
over a relatively small area for
humans. As a result, they experience greater impact stress
than cats experience. Furthermore, while head injuries are the
main cause of mortality in man,
cats rarely sustain fatal head
injuries.

Rawlins, commenting after the

were navigational observations

The scrap of paper, included in
the personal papers of former
JHU president and Peary family
friend Isaiah Bowman, was a
handwritten copy of a document
now stored with Peary's personal
papers in the National Archives.
This document was sealed in an
envelope marked, in Peary's wife
Jo's handwriting, as observations
of April 6, 1909 from the North
Pole. Rawlins calculated Peary's

position from the numbers, and
found it to be 121 miles from the
Pole. He accused Peary of being
not only a bad navigator, but a
liar. The Navigation Foundation
study concluded that the scrap
paper was from Peary's 1906
Polar expedition, and that the
envelope was mislabeled. Davies
speculated that Jo Peary had
mistakenly thought that this scrap
paper was a certain piece of
evidence that Peary had told her
"to guard with her life." Davies
believes that this critical evidence
may still lie unnoticed in the National Archives.
Although Peary's honor has

Blue Jays wrap up first winning season since 1974
Hopkins spanks stubborn Swarthmore 81-67 to remain in MAC SE title hunt
b), Patrick Furey
Johns Hopkins clinched its first
winning basketball season in fifteen years at the Newton White
Athletic Center last Wednesday
by defeating a stubborn Swarthmore team. 81-67. The victory
broke a two game losing streak
and kept the Jays in first place in
the MAC South East Division.
The last time Hopkins had a
winning record was 1973-74,
when they finished with a 17-9
record. The Blue Jays, under
Coach Gary Rupert, Sr., went on
to defeat Muhlenberg in overtime
for the MAC Southern title and
made a trip to the NCAA Division III tournament.
Hopkins jumped out to a quick
13-4 lead on Wednesday, sparked
by seven early points by
sophomore Andy Enfield. The
rest of the first half, however,
was marked by sloppy play from
both teams, as the Jays began to
play down to their 4-18
opponents.
After taking a 36-25 lead into
the intermission, the Jays were
unable to pull away from the
Quakers in the second half.
Swarthmore's Scott Gibbons
went on a shooting tear mid-way
through the second half, hitting
3 three-pointers to cut Hopkins's
lead to ten with just under eight
minutes remaining in the game.
That's when the Quakers'
tempers cost them a chance to get
back in the game.
After being called for an offensive foul, Swarthmore's Mike
Greenstone proceeded to pick up
a technical foul. When the
Quakers' coach, Lee Wimberly,
argued the call, he too was

slapped with a technical. Andy Enfield swished the three free
throws, and then connected from
fifteen feet on the ensuing possession to give Hopkins a commanding 66-51 lead with 7:07 remaining. On the night, Enfield was a
perfect 11-11 from the charity
stripe and led all scorers with
twenty points.
The Quakers again managed to
cut the Jays' lead to ten, this time
led by their freshman center
Robert Ruffin, who led
Swarthmore with nineteen points
and thirteen rebounds on the
night. Jedan Phillips, however,
broke his scoring slump late in
the game to seal the victory for
Hopkins. Phillips hit 6-9 from the
field and 5-6 from the line as he
finished with eighteen points.
Mike Latimore added fourteen
points to help the Jays improve to
6-2 in the conference and 13-7
overall.
The victory was a much needed one for the Jays. as it snapped
a two game losing streak and kept
them in the thick of the MAC title race. Hopkins was coming off
a tough road defeat at Widener,
where the Jays missed an opportunity to take control of the division race by falling 76-64 despite
twenty-one points from Andy
Enfield.
The MAC South East title race
is now a dogfight, to say the least.
Hopkins leads the division with a
6-2 record, but Ursinus,
Washington College, and
Widener are all right on the Jays'
heels with 5-2 records. The Blue
Jays' remaining divisional games
are next Wednesday at home
against the hapless Haverford
Fords and next Friday night
against Washington College in

Chestertown. Washington has the
most difficult schedule of the
teams involved in the title race,
as they must face Ursinus,
Widener, and Hopkins in the next
week. Ursinus has games left
against Widener, Washington,
and Swarthmore, while Widener
must face Ursinus, Washington,
and Haverford. What all of this
means is that it's anybody's race.
The worst that Hopkins can do,
barring a miracle upset by Haverford next Wednesday, is tie for
second place, which would mean
that the Jays' would have to
playoff for the right to face
Franklin & Marshall in the MAC
Tournament.
One thing is certain, however.
Hopkins will have a winning
record at the end of the 1988-89
basketball season. And like the
team of 1973-74, they will probably make the MAC playoffs.
After fifteen years of losing
basketball, what they do from
there is merely icing on the cake.

on Wednesday. If all goes right,

Swimmers earn national rankings
Men dunk Gettysburg, 137-60
by Michele Royce
The Swimming Jays finished
their dual meet schedule on Saturday in a competition against Gettysburg University and performed
as strongly as they have all season.
The women had an extremely
close meet, one that resulted in a
tied score of 101 points apiece.
The Lady Jays swam some excellent races, and the depth of the
team bolstered the multiple second place finishes to enable the
team to match the swimming of
Gettysburg. Unfortunately, the
four wins by the team were not
enough to put them over the top.
The 400 Freestyle Relay team of
juniors Mary Price and Laura
Carroll. and sophomores Melanie
Chellman and Anne Marie
Largay captured first place with
a time of 3:47.50 and freshman
breaststroker Betsy Batchelor
took first in the 200-yard event in
2:35.16. The other two Hopkins
first-place entries finished in
times that also qualified them for
the Division III National Championships. Sophomore Amy
Parke, along with teammates Batchelor. Largay, and Chellman
beat the qualifying standard in the
400 Medley Relay with a final'
time of 4:12.68, and Largay also
qualified in the 200 Butterfly in
2:12.00.
The men's swim team soundly
defeated Gettysburg 137 to 60, as
a result of some superb swims.

Sophomore Scott May took first
place in both the 1000 Freestyle
and the 200-Yard Backstroke
with times of 10:23.72 and
2:11.83 respectively. Individual
wins were also recorded by
sophomore John Paul Munnich in
the 200 Freestyle, senior Tom
Bryce in the 50 Free, freshman
Mark Richards in the 200 Fly,
junior Mark Rhoads in the
100-Yard
Freestyle. and
freshman Rob Dunn in the 500
Free. The 400 Medley Relay
team of sophomores Brent
Michell, Tom Sosnowski, Craig
Bernadini, and Steve Muchow
captured first with a 3:47.15, and
the freshman came through in the
200-Free Relay as Lars Hondorf,
Underwood. Jeremy
Pat
Kranowitz, and Dunn did the
same.
As the team continues its drive
to prepare for the NCAA Championships in mid-March, some
encouraging news has appeared
in the form of the Top Times
listing compiled by the College
Swimming Coaches Association
of America. The listing of the top
24 Division III swimmers in each
event as of January 23 contained
a number of Hopkins students
in the top ten positions. Junior
Chris Hussin was ranked sixth in
the 400 Individual Medley and
fifth in the 200 Back. Sophomore
Rich Quarles was listed in tenth
position in the 200 Breaststroke,
while the sixth spot in the 1000
Free was attained by freshman

Lars Hondorf. The JHU 400 Medley and 400 Free relay teams
also ranked in the top ten, with
fifth and eighth place respectively.
The team ranking, based on scoring of the individual event rankings. placed Hopkins in eighth
position. This puts the team in a
strong position entering the
Championship portion of the
season.
The women's team appears
even stronger, with several swimmers ranked first in the Division
III. Freshman Stephanie Dengler
has gained the top spot in the 500,
1000, and 1650 Freestyle rankings, as well as third in the 200
Freestyle list. Sophomore Amy
Parke is the highest ranked
200-Yard Backstroker, and
classmate Wendy Fenstamaker is
ranked third in the 200 Butterfly. Meanwhile sophomore
Melanie Chellman is ranked in
the top ten spots in two events:
third in the 400 I.M. and tenth in
the 200 I.M. With these multiple
top rankings, the team attained an
estimated position of sixth among
the Division III teams who had
submitted times.
The team is now preparing for
the UAA Conference Championships next week, in which the
men hope to defend their 1988 title and the women hope to better
last year's second place finish.

foil power West Point 18-9, they
were dealt a crushing defeat by
Duke, 3-24. After Saturday,
Hopkins's record stands at 11-6.
The foil team fenced .500 for
the day, beating Virginia 8-1 and
an undermanned VP!9-0, only to
lose to Army 4-5 and Duke 2-7.
Senior co-captain Dave Cohen
went 7-4, dropping three of his
four losses to Duke and bringing
his record to 40-8. Junior YenLen Tang distinguished himself
as being the only fencer with a
winning record against Duke, going 2-1 against them and finishing
7-3 on the day. Yen-Len's tally
for the year is now 19-15.
Freshman Rich Millhiser continues to rack up experience, fencing an even 5-5 on the day to improve to a nearly even overall
record of 19-20. Junior Mike
Greenfield was the only
undefeated Blue Jay on Saturday,
beating two foilsmen from
Virginia and one from VPI for a
perfect 3-0, lifting him to a 12-11
overall mark. Sophomore Li Kuo
Kong also fenced well, going 1-1
on the day to up his record to 5-2.
Hopkins Epee fenced strongly,
doing well in every meet except
one. Although 7-2 against
Virginia, 6-3 against VP!, and
8-1 versus Army, the Epeemen
still did not manage to score a win
against Duke. Senior co-captain
Robert E. Lee won all six of his
non-Duke bouts, making him 6-3
on the day and 26-17 on the
season. Sophomore Ian Hel fenced
4-5, bringing his season total
to 23-17. Sophomore Tim Train
continued to pull his weight with

a 7-5 record, making him 18-11
overall. Sophomores Andrew
Donalley and Dan Weaver both
fenced well; each had a 2-1
record, bringing their season
totals to 12-9 and 8-11
respectively.
The relatively inexperienced
Hopkins sabre team more than
held its own Saturday, posting a
winning record of 6-3 in three of
the four meets, while losing to
Duke 1-8. Everything clicked for
Junior Dave Howe, as his 9-1
record carried him out of a slump
and the team on to victory. Dave
also had the only sabre win
against Duke, improving his
record to 30-18. Sophomore Pete
Kim's exuberance was barely
edged out by his inexperience,
and he posted a 4-5 record, bringing himself to an overall 15-23.
Sophomore John O'Connell had
a frustrating day, as four 5-4
losses dragged his record down to
2-5, and his season record to
16-29. Sophomore Juan Suros,

while taking the winning bout
against VP!, was 1-2 for the day,
giving him a 3-10 season so far.
Junior co-captain A.J. Jablonowski finally returned to
the strip after two months out
with a leg injury, but all that time
without practice took its toll, as
he managed a 3-4 day to make
him 5-4 for the season.
We won the three easy meets,
which was expected," said coach
Dick Oles. "What wasn't expected was the way Duke pummeled us." Although the defeat
was a surprise, Oles considered
it a learning experience: "We've
been shown where our flaws
are." He expects no more surprises like Duke for the remainder of the season.

Hopkins as they take on RutgersNewark, the Citadel, Vassar,
Virginia Military Institute, and
William & Mary at home this
Saturday.

a $2-million computer system in
1982 capable of providing daily
readings on income and costs,

with targets set at the beginning
of each year.

academic divisions—or "revenue
centers," as they're called at
U.S.C.—to make mid-course
corrections in _case a revenue

shortfall becomes apparent. By
November, for example, a school
will know whether it should take
the revenue-increasing step of admitting more students for springsemester courses.
A dean might also ask a faculty member to quicken the pace of
a sponsored research project, in
order to speed the flow of
research dollars to the university, says John Curry, U.S.C.'s
vice-president for budget and
planning.

Hopkins Organization for Programming to

Since administrators vetoed a proposal to
have a large outdoor concert on the
lacrosse field during Spring Fair, "there
will not be a large outdoor show this
spring," said Holmes. "In fact, this spring
things are looking really bare."

scheduling difficulties in Shriver Hall.

For a variety of reasons, Indiana University, which has been

Whalen, director of budgeting at

$11-Million Shortfall at
Stanford
Even those universities that try
decentralization can't anticipate
every contingency. Stanford
University, which in the last two
years has begun moving toward
decentralized budgeting, recently projected an $11-million shortfall for 1989-90, and is now planning cuts to close the gap. The
university is trying to raise
$1.1 -billion, but has attracted
fewer unrestricted donations than
expected and faces unanticipated
costs and revenue shortfalls in
several academic areas.
Another concern about decen-

tralized budget plans is that they
can, like other schemes, break
down.
"When a university cuts its
faculty 10 per cent after raising
half a billion dollars, it's a very,
very bad situation," says Jerrold
S. Cooper, chairman of the Near
Eastern Studies department at
Johns Hopkins.
Until last year, Hopkins had no
serious problems with longstanding disparities between its
School of Arts and Sciences,
which is not well endowed, and
its School of Medicine, which has
not had problems attracting
funds.
But without a mechanism for
sharing surpluses among schools,
Hopkins officials faced a dilemma when they projected deficits
in arts and sciences and other programs that would outgrow the
capacity of a modest central
discretionary fund. Now,
however, the university will draw
$27-million over the next five
years from the medical school
and five other profitable divisions
to help bail out deficit-ridden
programs.
But the fix is only temporary,
increasing the pressure for cutbacks in arts and sciences and
other areas.
Many people angrily blame administrators for failing to anticipate problems earlier and for
fiscal mismanagement. Some say
the financial troubles threaten the
university's academic reputation.
But few have questioned the
budget system itself. "Decentralizaiton is a strength of
Hopkins," says Lloyd Armstrong, Jr., dean of arts and
sciences. "It shows the strength
of the structure that in times of
need, we are able to come
together and voluntarily reconfigure ourselves so we can get
over our difficulties."

Saving the Community
Members of the Hopkins Catholic
Community were shocked to learn last
week of the Baltimore Archdiocese's
abrupt decision to cut all funding for the
organization effective June 30 as part of
a larger series of fiscal cutbacks implemented to avoid a deficit next year.
With only nominal funding from the
University, the community will have
virtually no means of support.
While we at Hopkins have become all
too familiar lately with fiscal cutbacks,
sacrifices and reduced services, the Archdiocese's decision will hit particularly
hard. The Catholic Community is a
large and active student group at
Homewood. Under the guidance of
Fathers John Donohue and Bob
Michele, the community provides a
variety of services and programs including Sunday Mass on campus, as
well as on days of obligation and weekly
"Newman Nights" of dinner, discussion, and fellowship. The community
works closely with the Office of the
Chaplain, and has co-sponsored such
activities as Thanksgiving Dinner.
Particularly valuable, however, in
this divisive campus, is the sense of
enmmunity and belonging the organiza-

tion conveys to its members. The
Catholic Community provides weekly
opportunitites to interact socially and in- •
tellectually with a wide range of people in a relaxed, homelike setting. Such
opportunities, which are open to all, are
rare at Homewood.
The Archdiocese's decision to cut the
community's funding makes sense from
a purely fiscal standpoint: "studentparishes" simply do not generate
enough revenue to cover themselves.
Scarce resources must be allocated accordingly and in the neediest areas.
However, we do urge the Archdiocese
to reconsider its decision in terms of the
impact it will have at Homewood and
on its students. Approximately thirty
percent of the student population here
is Roman Catholic, about 150-200
students attend campus Sunday Mass,
and many more avail themselves of the
other programs and services.
It is therefore important to a large
number of students that a Catholic
presence be maintained at Hopkins. The
Archdiocese must surely consider the
spiritual needs of Catholic students at
a secular university very important.

As the debate continues—Is the
bookstore run by a bunch of
crooks, or do a bunch of crooks
run the bookstore?—one of the
oldest descriptions of the Hopkins
student has arisen by way of explanation. We are, goes conventional wisdom, altogether too
apathetic. Uninterested. Selfish.
What garbage.
Hopkins students are far from
apathetic, and we do not serve
ourselves by allowing this erroneous assumption to continue,
especially because it can be used
against us.
Two groups wind up citing this
alleged apathy with great
regularity. First (and more
forgivably), those trying to get
campuswide initiatives off the
ground, be it demand for improved housing or social programming, sometimes find themselves
frustrated when attendance is
poor or interest is low.
Understandably so, although the
success of recent ventures such as
Hoppy Hour and (ahem) Funk
Night would seem to attest
otherwise.
Second, and far less acceptable, the Administration often
ducks much needed reforms
(even when suggested by the
Human Climate Report) if they
aren't worried about student
response. Fair enough, one supposes, from their point of view.
Hopkins student activism,
rather, has been shaped by forces
which are unique to our school.
Because we are spread out all
over the Homewood area thanks

to our housing situation, the flip
side to life here is that we are integrated with the general community to a greater extent than
students at many other schools.
As a result, student involvement has not been of the campus
oriented variety, with all of the
ingrown ivory-tower perceptions
of the world beyond that can accompany more insular institutions. For a true picture of what
Hopkins is about, one has to look
beyond the strict confines of
Homewood.
"My instinct," said Chaplain
Van Utt, "is that there are probably twice as many students who
were placed in community service situations through our office
this year than did a year and a half
ago."
The Chaplain's office acts as a
conduit for community organizations in Baltimore who are looking for volunteers, and as such
can offer an interested student a
clearer picture of the options than
his or her vantage point might
afford.
Speaking of the Quality Time
publication which the Office puts
out, listing community service
possibilities in the area, Van Utt
emphasized that if, "students see
the Quality Time sheet and don't
see something that initially excites
them, we are usually able to find
something in the community
which is acceptable and interesting. Come in and talk to us
about it."

To the Editor:
It seems that Johns Hopkins is
not the only major Maryland institution forced by budget problems to make unprecedented cutbacks. The Archdiocese of
Baltimore, over a million dollars
in debt, is cutting funding to the
Hopkins Catholic Community as
of June 30. This decision was apparently made by people with
scant knowledge of our com-

munity other than as a line on a
ledger. While I understand the
extreme financial need of the
archdiocese, and I realize that
much of the work of the Catholic Church is more pressing than campus ministry, I
don't feel that the situation was looked over well
enough before the decision
was made.
The Hopkins Catholic Community is a very strong presence
on campus. With over 150
members, it's one of the largest
groups, and its range of activities
has been expanding steadily over
the past few years. More importantly, Newman House, the
Catholic Community center, is
one of the few friendly gathering
places for students in this relatively antisocial school. Enabling
people to go out on Thursday,
Friday, and Saturday nights and
see people other than their
housemates and classmates is probably the most important service
the Catholic Community performs. The Catholic Community
is very much a community,
something which the Human
Climate Task Force found very
rare at Hopkins, and Newman
House is a perfect place to relax,
meet people, and feel accepted.
The future of the Catholic
Community is very much up in
the air right now. The SAC gives
us next to nothing, and we have
,no other real sources of income.
At this point, both Fr. John
Donahue and Fr. Bob Michele
will probably be transferred
elsewhere at the end of the school
year. And although nothing has
been decided about Newman
House, the temptation for the archdiocese to sell the rowhouse for
needed funds must be great. This
is my worst fear—that we end up
not only priestless, but also
houseless. That would be a crippling blow.

enough to survive whatever happens, and we are far from giving

though, that one of the strongest

STUDENT INTERN PROGRAM
The Office of Admissions is opening a search for senior
admissions interns for the fall of 1989. We are looking for
people-oriented students to assist in the recruitment process by conducting the traditional on-campus interview.
Ideal candidates will enjoy speaking with prospective
students and their parents. Students must be poised and
mature and possess tact, diplomacy and the ability to put
high school students and their parents at ease.
To be eligible, a student must be a senior next fall in
good standing and plan to graduate in May 1990. Interns
must be able to talk about Johns Hopkins in an informed
and positive way, have a desire to participate in the
recruitment process and be comfortable interacting with
others.
Interns will be responsible for conducting admissions
interviews with prospective students and meeting their
parents and responding to their questions and concerns.
In addition, interns will compose written summary reports
of each interview. This will involve three or four hour-long
interviews each week from mid-September through midDecember. These are paid positions.
The initial interviews of interns will take place on March
28, 29 and 30 with second interviews scheduled on April
4, 5 and 6. The training program for those interns selected
will be just after final examinations and at the begilning
of first semester next year. Interns must be available at
these times.
Any student interested should send a letter indicating
his or her interest and listing two references, to Jerome
D. Schnyt man, Director of Admissions. Both references
must be members of the Johns Hopkins community,
preferably one member of the faculty and one from the
administration. Students should apply by March 10.

Why and how cats survive high-rise falls
by Zenah Wilson
Cats may not have nine lives,
but they do have the ability to survive falls that would be fatal for
most humans. While cats can survive falls from at least thirty-two
stories, humans rarely survive
falls greater than six stories (1
story equals 12 feet). According to
UCLA physiologist Jared Diamond. "this phenomena has not
received the scientific attention it
deserves."
An animal's recovery from a
fall is called high-rise syndrome.
High-rise syndrome has been
studied twice in cats. The more
recent study was made by Wayne
0. Whitney and Cheryl Mehlhaff
in 1984 at the Animal Medical
Clinic in New York. The

veterinarians based the study on
132 consecutive cases of high-rise
syndrome treated at the animal
hospital and on published reports
for human injuries. The distance

Whitney and Mehlhaff explain
the difference between cat and
human injuries using a few basic
principles of physics. Severity of
injuries is determined by the
stress a body experiences at impact. Impact stress is related to a
number of factors.
First, impact stress is directly
proportional to force. Force is
partially determined by the
distance fallen. As a body falls,
its velocity increases. The greater
the velocity at impact, the greater
the force. Force is also affected
by body mass—greater mass
equals greater force. The hardness of the surface also contributes to impact force. Softer
surfaces tend to 'give,' which
reduces the force applied to the
body. In this study, however,
almost all of the cats fell to concrete pavement.
Impact stress is inversely proportional to the area of the cat
which hits the ground. For instance, as a cat falls it twists
around until all four feet are facing downward. When the cat
lands, stress is evenly distributed
over four limbs. When human
adults fall, they tumble uncontrollably and usually land on
either their legs or their head.
When human babies fall, the
relatively large size of their heads
causes them to fall on their heads
while their arms extend outward
by reflex to break the fall. Consequently, stress is distributed
over a relatively small area for
humans. As a result, they experience greater impact stress
than cats experience. Furthermore, while head injuries are the
main cause of mortality in man,
cats rarely sustain fatal head

Blue Jays wrap up first winning season since 1974
Hopkins spanks stubborn Swarthmore 81-67 to remain in MAC SE title hunt
b), Patrick Furey
Johns Hopkins clinched its first
winning basketball season in fifteen years at the Newton White
Athletic Center last Wednesday
by defeating a stubborn Swarthmore team. 81-67. The victory
broke a two game losing streak
and kept the Jays in first place in
the MAC South East Division.
The last time Hopkins had a
winning record was 1973-74,
when they finished with a 17-9
record. The Blue Jays, under
Coach Gary Rupert, Sr., went on
to defeat Muhlenberg in overtime
for the MAC Southern title and
made a trip to the NCAA Division III tournament.
Hopkins jumped out to a quick
13-4 lead on Wednesday, sparked
by seven early points by
sophomore Andy Enfield. The
rest of the first half, however,
was marked by sloppy play from
both teams, as the Jays began to
play down to their 4-18
opponents.
After taking a 36-25 lead into
the intermission, the Jays were
unable to pull away from the
Quakers in the second half.
Swarthmore's Scott Gibbons
went on a shooting tear mid-way
through the second half, hitting
3 three-pointers to cut Hopkins's
lead to ten with just under eight
minutes remaining in the game.
That's when the Quakers'
tempers cost them a chance to get
back in the game.
After being called for an offensive foul, Swarthmore's Mike
Greenstone proceeded to pick up
a technical foul. When the
Quakers' coach, Lee Wimberly,
argued the call, he too was

slapped with a technical. Andy Enfield swished the three free
throws, and then connected from
fifteen feet on the ensuing possession to give Hopkins a commanding 66-51 lead with 7:07 remaining. On the night, Enfield was a
perfect 11-11 from the charity
stripe and led all scorers with
twenty points.
The Quakers again managed to
cut the Jays' lead to ten, this time
led by their freshman center
Robert Ruffin, who led
Swarthmore with nineteen points
and thirteen rebounds on the
night. Jedan Phillips, however,
broke his scoring slump late in
the game to seal the victory for
Hopkins. Phillips hit 6-9 from the
field and 5-6 from the line as he
finished with eighteen points.
Mike Latimore added fourteen
points to help the Jays improve to
6-2 in the conference and 13-7
overall.
The victory was a much needed one for the Jays. as it snapped
a two game losing streak and kept
them in the thick of the MAC title race. Hopkins was coming off
a tough road defeat at Widener,
where the Jays missed an opportunity to take control of the division race by falling 76-64 despite
twenty-one points from Andy
Enfield.
The MAC South East title race
is now a dogfight, to say the least.
Hopkins leads the division with a
6-2 record, but Ursinus,
Washington College, and
Widener are all right on the Jays'
heels with 5-2 records. The Blue
Jays' remaining divisional games
are next Wednesday at home
against the hapless Haverford
Fords and next Friday night
against Washington College in

Chestertown. Washington has the
most difficult schedule of the
teams involved in the title race,
as they must face Ursinus,
Widener, and Hopkins in the next
week. Ursinus has games left
against Widener, Washington,
and Swarthmore, while Widener
must face Ursinus, Washington,
and Haverford. What all of this
means is that it's anybody's race.
The worst that Hopkins can do,
barring a miracle upset by Haverford next Wednesday, is tie for
second place, which would mean
that the Jays' would have to
playoff for the right to face
Franklin & Marshall in the MAC
Tournament.
One thing is certain, however.
Hopkins will have a winning
record at the end of the 1988-89
basketball season. And like the
team of 1973-74, they will probably make the MAC playoffs.
After fifteen years of losing
basketball, what they do from
there is merely icing on the cake.

The women had an extremely
close meet, one that resulted in a
tied score of 101 points apiece.
The Lady Jays swam some excellent races, and the depth of the
team bolstered the multiple second place finishes to enable the
team to match the swimming of
Gettysburg. Unfortunately, the
four wins by the team were not
enough to put them over the top.
The 400 Freestyle Relay team of
juniors Mary Price and Laura
Carroll. and sophomores Melanie
Chellman and Anne Marie
Largay captured first place with
a time of 3:47.50 and freshman
breaststroker Betsy Batchelor
took first in the 200-yard event in
2:35.16. The other two Hopkins
first-place entries finished in
times that also qualified them for
the Division III National Championships. Sophomore Amy
Parke, along with teammates Batchelor. Largay, and Chellman
beat the qualifying standard in the
400 Medley Relay with a final'
time of 4:12.68, and Largay also
qualified in the 200 Butterfly in
2:12.00.
The men's swim team soundly
defeated Gettysburg 137 to 60, as
a result of some superb swims.

Sophomore Scott May took first
place in both the 1000 Freestyle
and the 200-Yard Backstroke
with times of 10:23.72 and
2:11.83 respectively. Individual
wins were also recorded by
sophomore John Paul Munnich in
the 200 Freestyle, senior Tom
Bryce in the 50 Free, freshman
Mark Richards in the 200 Fly,
junior Mark Rhoads in the
100-Yard
Freestyle. and
freshman Rob Dunn in the 500
Free. The 400 Medley Relay
team of sophomores Brent
Michell, Tom Sosnowski, Craig
Bernadini, and Steve Muchow
captured first with a 3:47.15, and
the freshman came through in the
200-Free Relay as Lars Hondorf,
Underwood. Jeremy
Pat
Kranowitz, and Dunn did the
same.
As the team continues its drive
to prepare for the NCAA Championships in mid-March, some
encouraging news has appeared
in the form of the Top Times
listing compiled by the College
Swimming Coaches Association
of America. The listing of the top
24 Division III swimmers in each
event as of January 23 contained
a number of Hopkins students
in the top ten positions. Junior
Chris Hussin was ranked sixth in
the 400 Individual Medley and
fifth in the 200 Back. Sophomore
Rich Quarles was listed in tenth
position in the 200 Breaststroke,
while the sixth spot in the 1000
Free was attained by freshman

Lars Hondorf. The JHU 400 Medley and 400 Free relay teams
also ranked in the top ten, with
fifth and eighth place respectively.
The team ranking, based on scoring of the individual event rankings. placed Hopkins in eighth
position. This puts the team in a
strong position entering the
Championship portion of the
season.
The women's team appears
even stronger, with several swimmers ranked first in the Division
III. Freshman Stephanie Dengler
has gained the top spot in the 500,
1000, and 1650 Freestyle rankings, as well as third in the 200
Freestyle list. Sophomore Amy
Parke is the highest ranked
200-Yard Backstroker, and
classmate Wendy Fenstamaker is
ranked third in the 200 Butterfly. Meanwhile sophomore
Melanie Chellman is ranked in
the top ten spots in two events:
third in the 400 I.M. and tenth in
the 200 I.M. With these multiple
top rankings, the team attained an
estimated position of sixth among
the Division III teams who had
submitted times.
The team is now preparing for
the UAA Conference Championships next week, in which the
men hope to defend their 1988 title and the women hope to better
last year's second place finish.

The fencing team had a day of
smooth victory and crushing
defeat last Saturday. While they
had relatively little trouble putting
down the University of Virginia
21-6, Virginia Polytech 21-6, and
foil power West Point 18-9, they
were dealt a crushing defeat by
Duke, 3-24. After Saturday,
Hopkins's record stands at 11-6.
The foil team fenced .500 for
the day, beating Virginia 8-1 and
an undermanned VP!9-0, only to
lose to Army 4-5 and Duke 2-7.
Senior co-captain Dave Cohen
went 7-4, dropping three of his
four losses to Duke and bringing
his record to 40-8. Junior YenLen Tang distinguished himself
as being the only fencer with a
winning record against Duke, going 2-1 against them and finishing
7-3 on the day. Yen-Len's tally
for the year is now 19-15.
Freshman Rich Millhiser continues to rack up experience, fencing an even 5-5 on the day to improve to a nearly even overall
record of 19-20. Junior Mike
Greenfield was the only
undefeated Blue Jay on Saturday,
beating two foilsmen from
Virginia and one from VPI for a
perfect 3-0, lifting him to a 12-11
overall mark. Sophomore Li Kuo
Kong also fenced well, going 1-1
on the day to up his record to 5-2.
Hopkins Epee fenced strongly,
doing well in every meet except
one. Although 7-2 against
Virginia, 6-3 against VP!, and
8-1 versus Army, the Epeemen
still did not manage to score a win
against Duke. Senior co-captain
Robert E. Lee won all six of his
non-Duke bouts, making him 6-3
on the day and 26-17 on the
season. Sophomore Ian Hel fenced
4-5, bringing his season total
to 23-17. Sophomore Tim Train
continued to pull his weight with

a 7-5 record, making him 18-11
overall. Sophomores Andrew
Donalley and Dan Weaver both
fenced well; each had a 2-1
record, bringing their season
totals to 12-9 and 8-11
respectively.
The relatively inexperienced
Hopkins sabre team more than
held its own Saturday, posting a
winning record of 6-3 in three of
the four meets, while losing to
Duke 1-8. Everything clicked for
Junior Dave Howe, as his 9-1
record carried him out of a slump
and the team on to victory. Dave
also had the only sabre win
against Duke, improving his
record to 30-18. Sophomore Pete
Kim's exuberance was barely
edged out by his inexperience,
and he posted a 4-5 record, bringing himself to an overall 15-23.
Sophomore John O'Connell had
a frustrating day, as four 5-4
losses dragged his record down to
2-5, and his season record to
16-29. Sophomore Juan Suros,

while taking the winning bout
against VP!, was 1-2 for the day,
giving him a 3-10 season so far.
Junior co-captain A.J. Jablonowski finally returned to
the strip after two months out
with a leg injury, but all that time
without practice took its toll, as
he managed a 3-4 day to make
him 5-4 for the season.
We won the three easy meets,
which was expected," said coach
Dick Oles. "What wasn't expected was the way Duke pummeled us." Although the defeat
was a surprise, Oles considered
it a learning experience: "We've
been shown where our flaws
are." He expects no more surprises like Duke for the remainder of the season.
Be sure to come cheer on
Hopkins as they take on RutgersNewark, the Citadel, Vassar,
Virginia Military Institute, and
William & Mary at home this
Saturday.

Instructions: Boy oh boy, did I want to do The Second Annual Gala SEX Quiz
this week. It could have become a Hopkins Valentine Tradition. For example,
last year's Question 11 was,"Who has the longest schlong on record?" Imagine
some biology grad students rummaging through one of their Mole Cell books,
scratching their heads. "Schlong? Schlong? Is that like ring finger? Or a big
toe?" No dice, guys. Actually, a popular jibe at my predecessor was that he needed
to run a sex quiz because he himself was undersexed. For that reason, I passed
on writing a sequel. Traditions die hard. (No pun intended.)
February 10 is as close as I can get to February 14, so I have prepared a grotesquely easy Valentine's quiz. Get your entries to the News-Letter hot tub (ne.e
Gatehousg, but the combination of the holiday and the BMA Sculpture Garden's
flooding our basement makes Hot Tub oh so appropriate) by February 15 at 5
p.m. And please, let's have some new people enter. There's always a first time.
(Both puns intended.)
Results: I certainly hope you people can relate to love as well as you can relate
to The Beatles.(What a world that would be.) And you all weren't even around
when The Beatles were popular! I can say "you all" because grad students don't
enter. They're still waiting for The Gala Leviathan Quiz I promised them. Well,
maybe sometime. Then again, maybe not. Probably not. Certainly not. I guess.
Lots of entries this week. The winner was Jonathan "Win One for the" Zipp
and the answers were: 1) Scrambled Egg; 2) Cry for a Shadow; 3) Michelle;
4) Badfinger; 5) Ringo; 6) Jesus Christ's disciples; 7)"Sky of blue and sea of
green"; 8) Mal Evans (Paul missed the photo session); 9) Pop Go the Beatles
or Saturday Club; 10) "Well she was just seventeen/A teenage beauty queen";
11) Christmastime; 12) Hello Little Girl, The Fourmost; 13) "Oompah, oompah, stick it up your jumper" and "Everybody's got one"; 14) Rain; 15) Bob
Dylan; 16) Lady Madonna; 17) Mahatma Gandhi; 18) Helter Skelter; 19) Julia;
20) John; 21) Michael Jackson (a/k/a Plasticman); 22) Savoy Truffle; 23) Dig
It, Don't Pass Me By, Flying, Maggie Mae, Octopus's Garden, and What Goes
On; 24) an anvil; 25) Peter Fonda!
Winners have two weeks to claim prizes. You must be 21 to collect the beer.
